title: kidney-research-uk-takes-another-tour-o-borders
story: BORDERS cycling event company, Hillside Outside, have announced that they will be partnering with Kidney Research UK once again for their Tour O The Borders sportive.This will be the second year the UK charity has been chosen as the events partner.The partnership was formed after one of the sportives participants was diagnosed with late-stage kidney failure in , meaning he had to drop out of the competition that year.Joseph McLean, who was only  years old at the time, received a successful kidney transplant in  from his father Tim, and both competed in the  Tour O The Borders, raising pound, for Kidney Research UK and Hillside Outside donating a further pound.Cyclists who wish to take part in the  Tour O The Borders, powered by Pirelli sportive, can either sign-up for the event as an inidual rider or as a team.Participants can also choose whether they want to ride as part of Team Kidney or as a regular cyclist.Those who decide to join Team Kidney commit to raising a minimum of pound in sponsorship for Kidney Research UK, and inwill receive a team kit, support before and during the event and a Team Kidney medal and certicate.Anyone who signed up and didnt select Team Kidney are encouraged to still fundraise for the charity.Harley Lothian, marketing manager for Hillside Outside, told us: ldquoWe are committed to demonstrating the many benefits of cycling through our event programme and Tim and Josephrsquos inspirational story exhibited just how phenomenal these benefits can be.ldquoWe are delighted to take this partnership forward for another year and continue to support the fantastic work that Kidney Research UK do each day in stopping this disease in its tracks.Tour O The Borders begins on Sunday, September  and leaves from Peebles on two closed-road routes - km or km, around the Borders.To book a charity place, visit tourotheborders

title: good-behaviour-order-45-year-olds-playground-disturbance
story: A Newtown St Boswells woman who admitted being involved in a disturbance at a local primary school has been ordered to be of good behaviour for the next three months.Jillian Reid, , of Glenburn Avenue, pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting and swearing, making threatening and abusive remarks as well as pushing another person on the body.The offence happened at Newtown Primary School on September .Sentence was deferred until April .

title: 27-year-old-denies-boxing-day-domestic-offences
story: A GALASHIELS man has been accused of assaulting a woman at a house in Kenilworth Avenue on Boxing Day.Curtis Watters, , of Laurel Grove, also denies behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting and swearing and making abusive and offensive comments towards his partner.The trial has been set for Selkirk Sherf Court on April  with an intermediate hearing on March .

title: hawick-veterans-charity-benefit-lottery-boost
story: A HAWICK-BASED charity, which aims to support armed forces and blue-light services veterans, is set to receive a sizeable donation from the National Lottery.The pound, windfall will help the FirstLight Trust provide services such as therapeutic support and model making sessions, helping the veterans to adjust to their civilian lives.The National Lottery Community fund money will allow the FirstLight Trust to develop a three-month pilot programme supporting veterans, holistically, who have experienced traumatic events.This programme will feature activities and holistic therapies designed to cover all areas of support for veterans.Some aspects of the pilot are already in place, including model making and archery sessions.FirstLight Trust support, as well as the model making sessions , can be accessed at the charitys cafeacute Hub based in Hawick. The archery lessons are currently held in Selkirk on a Friday afternoon.Dorinda Wolfe Murray, founder of FirstLight Trust, said: "We are over the moon about this funding, as it means that we can really start to create support and activity pathways for the veterans who access FirstLight Trust in Hawick and wider afield.ldquoWe know how important activities are in helping make friends, reduce isolation and increase mental and physical well-being.Alongside its current activities, the charity also gives veterans alcohol education, health and nutrition advice and money management courses, these are added to a tailored plan for each veteran to help them feel empowered to lead a fulfilled le.Therapeutic services for those living with PTSD or other mental health conditions will be provided with support from a chartered psychologist. The services available including eye movement desensitisation, reprocessing clinics and coping strategy sessions.Ms Wolfe Murray added: ldquoThe programme will run initially for three months and on completion project results will be evaluated and based on these results we hope to secure funding to implement a long-term plan.ldquoAny veterans living in the Borders with PTSD or other mental health conditions who feel they might benefit from our activities or therapy sessions are welcome to pop in to the hub and speak to one of our colleagues or contact our support worker who will be happy to provide all of the information about what support is available.The FirstLight Trust can be contacted at hawick@firstlighttrust or can be called on   .For more information about the charity and its services, visit www.firstlighttrust

title: coming-home-exhibit-local-artist
story: RETURNING home to the Borders inspired a local artists work for her upcoming exhibition.Caroline Mordues display, Coming Home, will open in Old Gala House on Saturday, March .The paintings are abstract interpretations of the Borders landscape, influenced by Carolines emotions upon ing to the Borders.Caroline said: "Irsquove recently moved back to the Borders, and itrsquos made such a dference to my work to be living in the heart of the Scottish Borders landscape again."Just outside my doorstep are the most inspiring views, and Irsquom often out walking with sketchbook and camera in hand.ldquoIrsquom excited to have this opportunity to exhibit my work in the wonderful setting of the Old Gala House."I feel that the paintings evoke the emotions and memories associated with this area, and I hope that visitors will experience this too."Some of Carolines paintings will be on sale from Old Gala House, allowing visitors to take home their favourite piece.Phoebe Stewart, Assistant Curator at Old Gala House told us: ldquoWersquore thrilled that Caroline is showcasing her work in the Pringle Room at Old Gala House."Through collaborating with artists, Live Borders is committed to making our communities happier, healthier and stronger and we find culture is a vital part of this process."This exhibition gives visitors the opportunity to purchase artwork created by a local artist, and what could be nicer than having your own piece of the Scottish Borders landscape at home Coming Home will be open until Sunday, June , and will be displayed in the Pringle Room.Old Gala House is open March to May, Tuesday-Saturday, am to pm, closed Mondays and Sundayspm to pm and Easter Monday am to pm June, Monday-Saturday, am to pm and Sundays pm to pm.Entry to the exhibit is free, donations are welcome.

title: leave-worries-behind-womens-well-being-enters-woods
story: A WOODLAND well-being project has sprung some new shoots ahead of spring.And the green-fingered organisers are inviting women from across the region to pull on their waterproofs and join in.Following the success of a teenage mental-health project Wild about Wellbeing over the past two years, Nature Unlimited is back with a new programme aimed at the grown-ups.Last week they launched Wild About Womenrsquos Wellbeing in Galashiels.And throughout this spring and summer they aim to host a range of activities such as upcycling old pallets into raised flower and fruit beds, cooking on the campfire, walking in the woods, and learning about nature.Geraldine Keita, who will be leading the programme, told us: ldquoWe are delighted to be able to offer a programme, specically for women, which is dferent from the usual mental health support on offer in the Borders."Getting out into nature is of huge benefit to wellbeing and we are very lucky to have a wealth of beautul, freely accessible woodland resources on our doorstep.The initial project for teenagers was regarded as a major success with girls reporting increased confidence, resilience and wellbeing - and it also led to an improved attendance at school.The new course is open to anyone aged  or over, who feels that they would benefit from being part of a supportive community, connecting with nature and being active in the outdoorsWild About Womenrsquos Wellbeing will be based at the Focus Centre in Galashiels and make use of the nearby Policies as well as woodlands at Drygrange near Earlston.Charlotte Maberly from Nature Unlimited added: "The Wild About Womens Wellbeing programme is very much in line with our other offerings - some of which are based at Drygrange Community Woodland, schools, others woodlands and other outdoor spaces."Nature Unlimited work with children and families, schools, young people and adults, supporting them to build resilience and improve their wellbeing through nature connection and group work in woodlands across the Scottish Borders."Having the chance to reconnect with nature can have a profound effect on our wellbeing and mental health, and we do hope that more people can benefit from the services we offer."Organisers believe the new programme will benefit women who may be struggling to cope with the everyday demands of le.As well as enjoying bushcraft and other woodland activities, the sessions allow women to come together and share their worries, to learn new skills and gain a sense of achievement.The new programme is due to start in April.If you would like to volunteer or participate on Wild About Womens Wellbeing, or any of their other Nature Unlimited programmes, contact Tara Bolland on   or email tara@natureunlimited.scot.

title: community-cop-conal-retires-duty
story: SELKIRK bid farewell to its community cop this week.But Police Scotland have already appointed someone to follow in Conal McEwans bootprints.PC McEwan officially retired on Monday following several years as the community officer for the Royal Burgh.He said: "I would like to thank the people of Selkirk for all the help they have given me and for making my le so much easier over the years."I would ask that they continue being the strong community that they are and continue pulling together to make Selkirk the place it is."PC Steven Gibson will take over as the community officer this month.Paying tribute to the outgoing officer, community council chair Alastair Pattullo said: "On behalf of the community council I would like to thank Conal for all he as done."He has certainly done us proud."

title: melrose-centenarian-celebrates-milestone-birthday
story: A PRIORWOOD Court resident has celebrated a special birthday as she turned  this week.Georgina Patterson celebrated her birthday with friends and family at the Melrose retirement home with music, party food and special cake to mark the occasion.Mrs Patterson will be known by many in the community as the founder of the Tweedbank Art Club, which she created alongside her daughter Nancy, after she retired.Before retiring however, Mrs Patterson worked in Buckingham Palace in the s, working first as a maid and housekeeper, before being promoted to a dedicated position caring for Princess Alice, Prince Philips mother.After Princess Alices passing in , Mrs Patterson was thanked by Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth, and was offered a full-time position as one of the Queens maids.Mrs Patterson had also worked all around the world, taking up seasonal positions in hotels. She even spent seven years working for the Biaritz Hotel in Jersey

title: customers-stuck-tesco-lift-two-hours
story: TESCO have vowed to keep their Galashiels lt out of operation until a full inspection is carried out.The announcement comes after customers were stuck in the elevator for more than two hours on Wednesday.Among the trapped shoppers was an elderly pensioner.Fire crews were called to the store at .am but it took until nearly pm before the shoppers were finally released.An ambulance was also in attendance.Following the release of the shoppers, a spokesman for Tesco told us: "Wersquore extremely sorry this happened and are pleased that our customers are now out of the lt."Wersquore grateful to the emergency services who were on site quickly and were able to resolve this."We wonrsquot be opening the lt again until wersquore completely confident it is working properly.

title: rachael-hamilton-promoted-shadow-cabinet-post
story: BORDERS MSP Rachael Hamilton has been appointed shadow cabinet secretary for Rural Affairs and Tourism.The move was announced this week following the election of Jackson Carlaw as Scottish Conservative party leader.Following the unveiling of the new shadow cabinet, Mrs Hamilton said that her background as a farmerrsquos daughter from Herefordshire and years of experience as an agronomist stands her in good stead for the role.The Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire member said: ldquoI am delighted to be appointed to be the shadow cabinet secretary for Rural Affairs and Tourism it is an opportunity I will relish.ldquoAs a farmerrsquos daughter, with many yearsrsquo experience as an agronomist and running a small hotel, agriculture and tourism is in my blood.ldquoI know first-hand the hours and hard work farmers put in, and they rightly should be rewarded for their efforts as the custodians of the countryside.ldquoDay to day in my constituency, and across Scotland, I have seen how the SNP continually let down our farmers.ldquoRural crime, poor broadband and a lack of farm grants all exacerbate the problems of rural Scotland.ldquoHardworking farmers want to grow their farm businesses and encourage the next generation to take the reins, but we see an SNP Government not fully supporting the sector."

title: sarah-launches-tokyo-passport-programme
story: ACTIVE children from across the Borders will be rewarded this summer by local leisure charity, Live Borders.To celebrate the  Tokyo Olympics the local active schools teams have devised Games Passports for youngsters to sweat their way towards bronze, silver and gold medals.Every primary school pupil in the Borders will be able to take part from next month.Great British hockey star Sarah Robertson, who is originally from Selkirk, officially launched Training for Tokyo  Games Passport this week.She said: "The Passport is a great initiative to get the kids across the Borders taking part in a number of sports.ldquoGetting kids out playing hockey, football, golf or tennis is brilliant, and with the excitement of the Olympics just around the corner it is a great chance to trial some of the sports like badminton, karate or table tennis.ldquoGrowing up, I played all dferent sports and I believe it has helped make me become a well-rounded hockey player with transferable skills from many sports.ldquoWho knows, this yearrsquos Passport may just uncover a future Borders Olympian.This is the fth Passport scheme that Live Borders has overseen following the  London Olympics,  Glasgow Commonwealth Games,  Rio Olympics and the  Gold Coast Commonwealth Games.The organisers hope to encourage primary pupils to enjoy a range of sports while trying to gain points towards a medal of their own.Senior Active Schools coordinator Paul Scott added: ldquoWe believe it is important to continue to build a lasting legacy in sport and physical activity participation in the Scottish Borders.ldquoOver the last eight years since London  we have ran four Passports and all of them have achieved huge success in encouraging more children to be more active, more often.ldquoWe canrsquot wait to get started and hope our young Bordersrsquo people enjoy the challenge while being healthier, happier and stronger.Each P-to-P and P-to-P Passport lists a number of dferent sports from the Tokyo Olympics.Pupils can accumulate points by taking part in as many of the sports as possible between Monday, March  and the conclusion of the Olympics on Sunday, August .For more information on the Training for Tokyo  Games Passport, visit www.liveborders.org.uk.

title: 30-communities-set-great-borders-river-clean
story: NEXT weekend more than  communities living along the Tweed and its tributaries are set for the biggest clean up ever held in the Borders.Throughout Saturday and Sunday, February  and March , around  eco-conscious volunteers will be rolling up their sleeves for the second Great Borders River Clean.The inaugural event in October attracted  rubbish collectors who bagged an incredible . tonnes of discarded wrappers, bottles and other environmentally damaging items.And with more and more communities signed up it is expected even more rubbish will be collected next weekend.St Marys School teacher Tom Rawson is the brains behind the Great Borders River Clean.He told us: "I have been blown away by the response to this event."There is something about rolling up your sleeves and getting stuck in to solve a common problem that has captured peoples imaginations."Its easy to see plastic pollution as never-ending but it can be solvedenough people see the effects and are willing to do something about it."This is something that young people, in particular, understand."I have been delighted to see schools, Scout groups, sports teams and community groups across the Borders engaging with this event."This is something that has been actively encourage by St Marys School in Melrose and I am fortunate to have time allocated to the organisation of this growing event."Scottish Borders Council is supporting the event by funding litter grabbers.And all rubbish collected will be transported to the regions waste transfer station.As well as cleaning up the Tweed at Innerleithen it is also planned for a tidy-up of the mountain bike trails on Saturday.Tom added: "I am keen to engage with anyone and everyone who enjoys being outside and who wants to help preserve and improve his or her natural environment."The Borders is a mountain biking paradise and so I am seeking to get that community actively involved with a joint river and trail clean at Innerleithen."Newcastletons title: 58-year-old-denies-public-indecency-charge
story: A -year-old man has appeared from custody at Jedburgh Sherf Court and denied a charge of public indecency.Clive Smith pleaded not guilty to standing at the window of his home in Moss Place, Newcastleton on Tuesday and exposing himself and carrying out a sex act causing members of the public to observe his conduct.A trial date has been set for April  at Jedburgh Sherf Court with an intermediate hearing on April .

title: selkirk-gallery-strikes-gold-new-exhibition
story: A BORDERS-based artist is bringing some Byzantine influence to a small museum in Selkirk.From next month gold will dominate Halliwells House as Alexandra Warren launches her exhibition in the Robson Gallery.Born in New York and raised in Greece, Alexandra developed a love of Cycladic sculpture and Byzantine icons.And despite spending the past  years in the Scottish Borders her work is still heavily influenced by the continuation of the Roman Empire.Her magnicent human figures and extensive use of gold leaf reflect a letimes influence.Alexandra told us: ldquoIrsquom very happy and honoured to have the opportunity of a solo exhibition in the lovely Robson Gallery in the historic Halliwellrsquos House, Selkirk.ldquoIrsquoll be presenting large figurative pieces and a series of small figurative paintings."Each piece is created with gold leaf, paint and shellac on wood , all inspired by Greek Byzantine icons - since I was lucky enough to have spent my childhood in Greece.rsquorsquoThe Traces of Gold exhibition opens on Saturday, March  and runs until the end of May.Assistant curator Phoebe Stewart said: ldquoWersquore delighted that Alexandra Warren is exhibiting with us in the Robson Gallery at Halliwellrsquos House."Her exquisite work, reminiscent of Greek Byzantine art, is a must-see."

title: tenants-help-shape-eildons-new-green-housing-revolution
story: LOCAL social landlord, Eildon Housing, has confirmed work will begin next month on a further  new family homes in the Borders.And they hope research from their green-building revolution will lead to even better eco-friendly homes in the future.With the completion of three Passivhaus houses at Springfield Place in St Boswells over the next few weeks, attentions will turn to a similar -house development in Westruther.Two families from each development will provide regular feedback regarding their new homes.And the findings will help shape future projects.Nile Istephan, chief executive of Eildon, believes there is high demand for the eco-friendly three- and two-bedroom properties.He said: "Built to Passivhaus standard, the homes generally need  percent less energy for heating and hot water than standard buildings with very low running costs."This is another stride towards our fight against fuel poverty."Westruther is one of four developments forming Eildonrsquos green pilot which will see up to  new green homes built using dferent building methods."Working in partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Construction Scotland Innovation Centre and Glasgow School of Art the pilot will compare construction costs, time to build and the experience of tenants living in the homes."The Westruther homes are expected to ready for new tenants by the spring of .Mr Istephan added: "We will be looking to work closely with two families at each of the green projects to for a period of time when they move in."The results will be used to determine not only the future building programme for Eildon, but also lead the way for how Scottish homes are built and lived in, in the future. "

title: thought-provoking-exhibition-brings-borders-history-life
story: AN exhibit at Hawick Museum is showcasing the work of three local artists who were inspired by artefacts held by the museum.With the rural Borders at the heart of this exhibit, Liz Douglas, Felicity Bristow, and Jenny Pope each created their interpretations of ious items in the museums collection.Liz Douglass contribution was inspired by a shepherds lantern from the th century from the Live Borders archive and her wider work has been influenced by the thirteen drty days of .Jenny Popes work is more sculptural, using materials such as porcelain, felt, and paper and testing their usage limits.She was inspired by the Poachers Riddle from the museums Domestic Room to create tools with new s.Her portrayal of items which appear weathered "to suggest the uncertainty and changes we all face as human beings".Fellow sculptor, Felicity Bristow, was also inspired by items found in the Domestic Room, with her work looking to create pauses which calm the body and mind after being physically and mentally lsquofloodedrsquo by natural, physical and emotional external sources.Richard White, Assistant Curator at Hawick Museum, said: "We are delighted to have these artists exhibiting in our newly refurbished Scott Gallery."This is an interesting exhibition which is sure to make people think."As a charity, Live Borders aims to make people healthier, happier and stronger and visiting this exhibition should certainly help make people happier."Tools for Survival: A Conversation Between Three Artists runs until  March  in the Scott Gallery at Hawick Museum. Opening times: Monday to Friday : to :, Sunday : to :. Closed Saturdays.Admission is free and donations are welcome.

title: across-pyrenees-melrose
story: NEXT SundayMelrose Music Society continues its concert season with Across the Pyrenees: French and Spanish Music for the Saxophone.The concert, generously sponsored by the Tunnell Trust, will give the audience an exciting and colourful exploration of the cultural sympathy and musical styles of the two countries on either side of the Pyrenees.Saxophonist Jonathan Radford studied at Cheethamrsquos School of Music and the Conservatoire National Supeacuterieur de Musique de Paris with Claude Delangle, graduating in  with a Masters Degrees with distinction in both saxophone and chamber music.Pianist Eleanor Kornas, from Derbyshire, graduated with a First Class Honours Music degree from Cambridge University, and she was an Adami Award Junior Fellow in Piano Accompaniment at the Royal College of Music. She now works as a Staff Accompanist at Cheethamrsquos School of Music having performed as a soloist and accompanist both in the UK and internationally.The French side of their programme includes works by Milhaud, Caplet, Lauba, Faureacute, Maurice and Borne, the last piece a lsquoFantasiersquo based on melodies taken from Bizetrsquos Carmen opera. The Spanish side is represented by music of Manuel de Falla and Pedro Iturralde.The concert starts at .pm at Melrose Parish Church Hall.Tickets, priced at pound and free for accompanied school-age children, are available at the door.

title: remember-galashiels-1970
story: MEMBERS of a Galashiels history group are inviting you to take a walk down memory lane from next month.The latest Old Gala Club exhibition relives .From a year of long-hair, flares, Apollo  and the Beatles disbanding, the club members have brought together a fascinating exhibition of le in Galashiels.The exhibition at Old Gala House, showcases photographs from their extensive collection along with toys, records, sports memorabilia, stamps, pre-decimal coins and even a vintage chemistry set.Murray Dickson, president of the Old Gala Club, told us: ldquoWe always enjoy working in partnership with Live Borders on our annual exhibition at Old Gala House."This year we are rolling back  years to  and, using photographs and objects from our archives and collections, we hope to give townsfolk and visitors a flavour of what le was like then.The Galashiels in the s exhibition will run from Saturday, March  through until October  in the Museum Room at Old Gala House.Phoebe Stewart, assistant curator at Old Gala House said: ldquoWersquore delighted that The Old Gala Club is exhibiting with us for the season."It will be a fascinating trip back through the years to see what Galashiels was like."

title: famously-hawick-set-tour
story: A PROJECT to promote Hawick has just launched an imaginative range of guided tours.Famously Hawick wants to provide visitors with an experience of the towns rich manufacturing heritage.And they hope the new all-year-round tours will demonstrate why Hawick gained an international reputation for producing high quality goods.These new lsquoexperience packagesrsquo are the latest development from the collaboration of premium producers in the town.Successfully launched last year, Famously Hawick promotes The Borders Distillery, Hawico, Johnstons of Elgin, William Lockie and Lovat Mill as the Cashmere, Tweed and Whisky town.But based on feedback, visitors didnt want to just buy the quality goods, they wanted to see where they came from and how they were made.As a result, Famously Hawick tour packages have been created.There are three dferent experience packages available - An Introduction to Famously Hawick, which is an independently led tour, The Famously Hawick Experience, which is a fully guided tour including lunch, and the Famously Hawick Gold Standard, which is a fully bespoke tour.The tours can be booked online at www.famouslyhawick

title: council-spend-730k-new-hq-canteen-reception
story: COUNCILLORS are set to rubber-stamp spending more than pound, on creating a new reception and canteen at their headquarters.As part of the forthcoming years budget proposals, pound, has been earmarked for the building with a further pound, to be spent on demolition of the old canteen.The proposals are part of the planned   capital spend.A spokesman told us: "The existing staff canteen building at Scottish Borders Council headquarters, which also contains meeting rooms and storage, is le expired."The council is establishing a lsquograb and gorsquo facility as part of improvement works to the public reception area of the main headquarters building."This will enable the canteen building to be demolished, delivering savings in respect of rates, maintenance, lighting and heating.

title: jim-clark-driving-trail-cover-scenic-borders
story: A CROSS-BORDERS driving trail has been created for visitors wanting to learn more about rallying icon, Jim Clark.The -mile adventure trail will take drivers on a tour of the Borders with pit-stops showcasing regional beauty spots as well as locations steeped in motorsport history.Launched by the Jim Clark Trust, the trail hopes to engage visitors and help them discover the places and stories behind the former double Formula One Champion, Clark.The trail starts and ends at the Jim Clark Motorsport Museum, Duns, and is completely free of charge as it is designed to enhance the experience had at the museum.From the museum, a trail map guides visitors to Chirnside, Jim Clarks hometown and final resting place, then to Berwick-Upon-Tweed where Jim began his racing career. After crossing back into the Borders over the Union Chain Bridge, towards Winfield Airfield, home of the first Scottish Motor Racing Meeting.And before the final stop back at the Museum, the last featured destination is the Charterhall Airfield, where Jim saw his first Scottish motor race. Motorists can then refuel at the Jim Clark Cafeacute Bistro.Ben Smith, chair of the Jim Clark Trust told us: ldquoThe Jim Clark Motorsport Museum is fast becoming a magnet for classic and sports car enthusiasts."The Jim Clark Trail is an exciting new adventure for all visitors, on a far more modest scale to the North Coast , a stunning driving tour celebrating the rich heritage and culture of the Borders.Jim Clark was a world-renowned racer, having won the Formula One World Championship in  and , as well as the Indianapolis  in . At heart he was a Borders farmer, working on his familys farm at Edington Mains.Sir Jackie Stewart OBE, Honorary President of the Trust, recalled: ldquoHe was the best."Shy almost introverted, modest, he was a Borders farmer after all. And he never stopped being a Borders farmer.The trail map not only guides visitors to locations in the history of Jim Clark, but prompts tourists to visit other Borders market towns such as Coldstream, Kelso and Jedburgh.The Jim Clark Trust have also collaborated with Scottish Borders Council, Live Borders, and the Midlothian Borders Tourist Group to support local tourism and businesses. They are encouraging local businesses to get in contact to help develop the trail further.Any businesses wishing to join the trail should contact the Trust at info@jimclarktrust.The Jim Clark Motorsport Museum will open for its new season on Sunday, March . For more information, visit www.jimclarktrust.

title: silent-disco-set-mac-return
story: FOLLOWING last years sell-out club night, silent disco is set for ato the Mac Arts.More than  head-phoned revellers enjoyed the two silent sessions in Galashiels in November.And just as many are expected when Silent Knightsnext month.Rikki Toner from Silent Knight said: "At a silent disco instead of loud music participants will be given headphones and music will be transmitted to everyone wearing the headsets."To those watching it appears to be a room dancing to no music."Silent Knights will host an afternoon family silent disco, between pm and pm.And then its the over s only from pm to midnight.There will be three dferent music channels to choose from at each disco.Rikki added: "The family event will feature a channel of Top  pop, dance-along favourites and a channel of classics for the parents."The evening adult event will see three live DJs playing simultaneously with guests able to flick between the DJs, with several genres and eras of music covering the three channels."The silent discos will take place on Saturday, March .Tickets, priced at pound for the family event and pound pound for the evening disco, are available from www.macarts.scot

title: gallery-grand-opening-dream-come-true-owner-artist
story: AN Innerleithen gallery is set to officially launch in the town next month, supporting the career dreams of its owner and the launchs featured artist.Kate Hayes opened Solo Gallery, which sits at  High Street, Innerleithen, in December , but the gallerys official launch will be held on Saturday, March  and will highlight the work of landscape artist, Louise Turnbull.Kate moved to Galashiels in  after working in business, and began plans for Solo Gallery in the summer of .She told us: "Moving to the Borders and opening a gallery has been a real change of pace for me, but the chance to show the work of new and established artists to potential buyers is a real joy."Im delighted that Louise will be the featured artist at the gallery opening - her work is full of emotion."Louise Turnbull swapped a career in learning and development for one in art in , and moved to Walkerburn where she had her own studio space and access to the Tweed Valley for inspiration.She said: "Im loving my new le as a professional artist and I hope I can inspire a few more people to follow their dreams."Im delighted that Im able to show off my latest work at Solo Gallery and its exciting to know that Kate has brought a great new gallery to my doorstep."Solo Gallery will officially open on Saturday, March , between pm and pm.

title: students-delight-cashmere-panel-scarf-designs
story: A PARTNERSHIP between a Galashiels cashmere company and secondary schools across the Borders has led to some eye-catching designs.And,youre lucky, you could be wearing one of them round your neck next winter.In conjunction with Developing Young Workforce Borders and Heriot-Watt University, third-year pupils at four dferent schools took part in the Sinclair Duncan scarf design competition.And the expert  were blown away during the day of presentations.Alistair McDade, business development director at Sinclair Duncan, told us: "The standard of all the designs was extremely high."Each team had approached the project in a dferent way and it made our job as lists very dficult."Itrsquos been fantastic to witness the students from Heriot Watt guide the pupils in creating a design concept and translating it into a woven product."Since September teams from Berwickshire High, Galashiels Academy, Jedburgh Grammar and Earlston High, along with their Heriot-Watt University student mentors, have learned about market research and product marketing, taken part in design workshops, enjoyed mill tours and Computer-Aided Design experience, and honed their presentation skills.And last week the design students from all four schools went head-to-head at the Sinclair Duncan studio.The judging  was tasked with choosing a design to be made into a cashmere scarf for sale at Abbotsford Visitor Centre.And a second design also had to be selected to be turned into a sash for presentation to the Best Dressed at Kelso Races Ladies Day in May.Following y deliberation, Earlston High was announced the Abbotsford winner.Tania Murray from the Abbotsford Trust said: "We are very much looking forward to seeing this beautul design as a cashmere scarf."The inspiration, which was lsquoAbbotsford at nightrsquo is very fitting."The team will also be involved in creating a display for the scarf within the shop so they have to think about the full journey of designing, manufacturing and selling a product."Jedburgh Grammars Eildon@Ladies Day design was selected for the Kelso Races winners sash.Further awards were presented to Galashiels Academy, who received the Sinclair Duncan Award for design Excellence, exhibiting the strongest skills in design research and application of technical knowledge.And Berwickshire High School was awarded the Developing Young Workforce Award for work-skills excellence.Sara Ward from Developing Young Workforce commented: "It was great to see this team embrace the project fully and demonstrate such strong links between their learning and skills required for the workplace."Manufacturing starts straight away and the finished scarves will be on the shelves towards the end of May.All of the teams will be presented with a limited edition scarf made from their winning designs.They will also be on display at The Borders Textile Towerhouse in Hawick.

title: cops-search-attempted-parcel-snatcher-galashiels
story: POLICE are appealing for help following an attempted parcel snatch in Galashiels on Saturday morning.The delivery driver managed to fight off the masked thug at around .am in Beech Avenue.Officers believe a second man nearby was an accomplice.And they are appealing for help to catch the two men.Detective Constable Narelle Allan said: ldquoThis incident has left the victim understandably shaken and he managed to hold on to the parcel that the suspect tried to take from him which is now undergoing further investigation.ldquoWersquore eager to hear from anyone who may have been in the Beech Avenue area of Galashiels on Saturday morning and who witnessed what happened, or any suspicious behaviour or iniduals in the vicinity beforehand.ldquoEqually anyone with any information to assist our inquiries is urged to come forward.The attempted thief was wearing a black balaclava, grey trousers and a black hoodie.Anyone with information should call Police Scotland on .

title: samira-ahmed-agrees-settlement-bbc-following-equal-pay-tribunal-win
story: Samira Ahmed and the BBC have reached a settlement after the presenter won her equal pay claim against the corporation.An employment tribunal announced last month that the Newswatch host should have been paid the same as Jeremy Vine earned on Points Of View.The BBC had argued that the two presenters were not doing similar work.Now the broadcaster has said in a statement: ldquoSamira Ahmed and the BBC are pleased to have reached a settlement following the recent tribunal.The judgment in Samira Ahmed v BBC handed down by Judge Harjit Grewal in the Central London Employment Tribunal is now available online: https:t.co oevWxPgTVNmdash Judicial OfficeJanuary , ldquoSamira is a highly valued BBC presenter and now these matters have been concluded we all want to focus on the future.ldquoWe look forward to continuing to work together to make great programmes for audiences. Neither the BBC, Samira or the NUJ will be commenting further on this case.Ahmed asked why she was paid pound per episode of Newswatch while Vine was paid up to pound, for each episode of Points Of View, work she described as comparable.vw,vw,px, px"Jeremy Vine The corporation had argued that Newswatch was a ldquorelatively niche programme which aired on the BBC News channel, while describing Points Of View as ldquoextremely well-known.Ahmed said in a statement after winning her claim that ldquono woman wants to have to take action against their own employer.ldquoI love working for the BBC. Irsquom glad itrsquos been resolved.She added: ldquoIrsquom now looking forward to continuing to do my job, to report on stories and not being one.She has been among several female talents at the BBC to voice their concerns over pay equality following an outcry over former China editor Carrie Graciersquos salary compared to male colleagues in similar roles..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Samira Ahmed agrees settlement with the BBC following equal pay tribunal win

title: stranded-travellers-set-return-home-canary-islands-airports-reopen
story: UK holidaymakers stranded in the Canary Islands are to begin ing home after most of the Spanish archipelagorsquos airports reopened following a Saharan sandstorm.Departures from Gran Canaria, Lanzarote, La Palma and North Tenere were able to take off on Monday morning, but those departing from South Tenere continued to be grounded.Flights to and from the airports were cancelled, suspended or erted over the weekend due to poor visibility.vw,vw,px, px"Passengers queuing at Tenere South airport Passengers posted photographs of people sitting on airport floors waiting for more information.Greg Horsman, , was on holiday with his girlfriend and his friends on a Tui cruise and was due to fly home to Manchester on Saturday evening.However, they were forced to stay in Gran Canaria for another two nights due to the storm.vw,vw,px, px"Clouds of red dust formed across the Canary Islands on Sunday He told the PA news agency: ldquoItrsquos frustrating. Wersquore just ready to be home.A spokeswoman for Tui said: ldquoWe would like to sincerely apologise to customers for the disruption caused by the adverse and changeable weather conditions in the Canary Islands on Saturday February  and Sunday February .ldquoThe safety of our customers and crew is always our highest priority and we are working tirelessly to find the best solutions for all our customers..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Stranded travellers set tohome as Canary Islands airports reopen

title: josh-taylor-reveals-opponent-first-defence-world-titles
story: The Prestonpans super lightweight champion ndash who added the WBA belt to his IBF title by beating highly rated American Regis Prograis on points in the final of the World Boxing Super Series in London last October ndash will have to fulfil his mandatory obligation against -year-old Khongsong before turning his attention to locking horns with WBC and WBO belt holder Jose Ramirez in a unication bout.Like Taylor, Khongsong, who is the IBFs mandatory challenger, has won all of his  bouts, but the Thai boxer has only fought once outside of his home country.Taylor is dreaming of getting his hands on all four belts in the lbs ision but will also have to wait for the outcome of Ramirezrsquos defence against Ukrainian Viktor Postol on February .Postol and Taylor have already squared off, having fought each other in the summer of .The fight, which took place at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow, saw Taylor emerge with a unanimous points decision over Postol, who previously held the WBC title.Taylor said: ldquoRamirez has the mandatory against Postol in February and I have to do it with my IBF belt with this guy from Thailand.ldquoI need to get that out of the way and he needs to get Postol out of the way.ldquoEvenPostol comes through that hersquoll be the guy I want because hersquoll have the two belts.Taylor, who split with Barry McGuigans Cyclone Promotions last week after signing with American promoters Top Rank, is hoping to be on home soil against Khongsong but concedes he will likely have to travel across the Atlantic for a potential bout with American Ramirez.Speaking to IFLTV, he added: ldquoIrsquom hoping Irsquoll have a defence in Scotland before then going Stateside to chase the Ramirez fight.ldquoI canrsquot see Ramirez coming over here, Irsquod push for it but I have to go to America.ldquoIrsquoll go there and see my name up in bright lights."The future is bright and I canrsquot wait to get going.ldquoThat fight has to happen at some point this year, thats my goal and focus, becoming undisputed king and be the first [Scottish] man to do it since Ken Buchanan.

title: bid-decontaminate-former-musselburgh-gasworks-asbestos
story: National Grid Property Holdings Ltd has once again applied for planning consent to carry out ldquosite remediation work on vacant, disused scrubland off Balcarres Road, near the racecourse and East Lothian Outdoor Learning Centre.A previous planning application was withdrawn last year.A company spokesperson said: ldquoThe application has been resubmitted following clarication that a portion of land along the access route to the site is held by East Lothian Council.A design statement submitted with the current plan said sporadic asbestos fibres across the site and localised pockets of spent iron dioxide were identied.Fewer than . hectares, the former gasworks site is surrounded by three-metre sandstone walls and the main part is accessed by a lockable gate, with an unsecured area of public open space beyond.It is understood that gas production started there in  and two gasholders were located on the site. By , the operation had expanded and two additional gasholders were installed. A detailed site plan from  showed another -column gasholder in place.Gas production ceased in  and by  the site had been cleared of all the above-ground gasworks structures.In , remediation works were undertaken about , tonnes of contaminated material were taken off-site to licensed landfill facilities and replaced with lsquocleanrsquo imported stone-filled material. Further remediation work was undertaken in .A planning statement said: ldquoThe proposed remediation scheme will be an important step in bringing the presently vacant, disused site into beneficial use. However, it is likely that further works will be required to address risks associated with asbestos in soil impacts.ldquoFurther remediation and protective works may be required to facilitate a future built development but, at present, there are no specic plans pertaining to the site.The proposed work will involve the excavation, segregation and off-site disposal to landfill and or an off-site treatment facility of the known remaining gasworksrsquo by-product contamination.Spent iron oxide, localised Light Non-acqueous Phase Liquids , tar-impacted contents of small brick and concrete structure will be removed and replaced with uncontaminated material.Localised free productresting on top of the groundwater table will be removed off-site and existing vegetation will be cleared.Vehicle access to enable the work to take place will extend from the timber fence on the sitersquos current southern boundary across the open green space and car park to connect with Balcarres Road.Due to the surrounding road network, ldquocareful management will be required to secure a ldquosafe and controlled approach to waste removal.A detailed traffic management plan will be prepared in due course to ensure that the limited duration of vehicle movements maintains appropriate access to the road network and parking for residents and businesses, and to minimise and address material being brought onto the public highway or right-of-way footpath.Hannah White, land regeneration manager at National Grid Property, said: ldquoWersquove submitted a planning application for environmental improvement work at the site.ldquoThis is part of a UK-wide programme of improvement works, which we always carry out safely and with as little disruption as possible.ldquoIf our application is approved, we hope to start work in the coming months and will be able to give people more details then.

title: olympic-swimmer-duncan-scott-meet-youngsters-musselburgh
story: The exclusive event has been planned as the prize for enjoyleisure winning the Learn to Swim Service Provider of the Year , sponsored by Scottish Water, at Scottish Swimmingrsquos annual awards.enjoyleisurersquos programme is already helping , children in the county to learn to swim.Duncan, Learn to Swim ambassador and winner of multiple medals at Olympics, Commonwealth Games and World Championships, takes part in a fun pool session at Musselburgh Sports Centre tomorrow .As well as sharing swimming top-tips and giving swimming demonstrations to the children from across East Lothian, he will also host a question and answer session.Duncan became the most decorated swimmer ever at a Commonwealth Games after finishing Gold Coast  with six medals to his name.He also holds the British record of .sec for the m freestyle, won two silvers at his first Olympic Games in Rio and is the National Lottery Athlete of the Year.Karen Ferguson, swimming development manager at enjoyleisure. said: "After launching the Learn to Swim programme in September , we devised a strategy to create a quality teaching programme and an inclusive learning environment and the programme has just grown from there."We offer free lessons to draw youngsters into the programme that wouldnrsquot normally come along as it gives them the opportunity to see how beneficial it is."Itrsquos amazing to see how the lessons are able to give children so much confidence."Getting the Learn to Swim programme to this point has been a real team effort from everyone involved, so we are really excited to be recognised for our dedication and rewarded with a visit from Duncan."

title: east-lothian-council-developer-lacks-honour
story: Councillor Norman Hampshire said he was ldquoextremely disappointed after Taylor Wimpey applied to have its commitment to upgrade an informal path at new housing in Musselburgh as part of its planning consent discharged.One mother who attended a meeting of the planning committee said her family moved into the new housing after she was told the path would be created, offering a safe route to school for her children.However, lawyer Alasdair Sutherland, who represented Taylor Wimpey at the meeting, said it had come to light the developers did not own the land the path was on.He argued that without ownership of the land, the council could not enforce the condition and make the developers upgrade the path.The path, known locally as The Drt, runs from the new housing at Pinkie Mains down to the railway bridge and links Musselburgh to Wallyford Railway Station and Wallyford Primary School.Kaye Nicoll told the committee that she currently has to cross  roads to get her daughter to school after moving onto the new estate two years ago.She said: ldquoWe were delighted when Taylor Wimpey told us there was going to be a path almost from the back of our house.ldquoI think every child should walk to school and my daughter is now nine and desperate to walk on her own.ldquoI cannot allow her to cross all those roads on her own, some of them are quite dangerous for a nine-year-old.The committee was told that Taylor Wimpey was granted planning permission to build  houses and  flats at Pinkie Mains in March  and one of the conditions attached was that The Drt ldquoshall be constructed to an adoptable standard, including street lighting, along the extent of it between Pinkie Terrace and the East Coast Main Line under bridge.It also called for new connections to be added from two cul-de-sacs in the development.An application to have the condition discharged was made after East Lothian Council planning officers threatened to take enforcement action over the firmrsquos failure to construct the path.Councillor Hampshire said: ldquoI am extremely disappointed a company like Taylor Wimpey have taken a decision not to honour a condition proposed by this planning committee.ldquoThey actually used this as a way to sell properties to people this is not an honourable thing to do.Councillor Colin McGinn said: ldquoSurely the developer would look at the conditions and make sure they could meet them before starting to build because in this case it seems they have just built and built and then looked at the conditions.Keith Dingwall, head of planning, told the committee that upgrading the path would cost pound,.Councillor Kenny McLeod pointed out the cost was equivalent to the price of one of the two or three bedroom houses built on the estate.And ward councillor Andrew Forrest said he had been at the original planning committee meeting which approved the housing plans.He said: ldquoI am disappointed by the attitude of Taylor Wimpey. They waxed lyrical about what this development would do for the area and my understanding was they were going to develop that path.The committee voted unanimously to reject the application to discharge the condition.Taylor Wimpey described the decision as disappointing, saying it would now consider its next move.Pauline Mills, land  planning director for Taylor Wimpey East Scotland, said: ldquoThis condition was added to the consent without any prior engagement with us, which isunusual.ldquoWe have always been aware of the planning condition to provide upgrades to the path known locally as The Drt and, from a very early stage following the issue of the planning consent for ourdevelopment in Musselburgh, we have attempted to engage with East Lothian Council about thevalidity of this condition.ldquoThe path is located on land that we do not own and therefore have no control over, and it is outwith the boundary of the development.ldquoWe have therefore been of the view since it was imposedthat it is not valid as part of the consent and have made the council aware of that view.ldquoWe have met to discuss this matter fully with the council in order to find an alternative solution andremain committed to do so.

title: senseless-vandals-hurl-bottles-nursery-window
story: On the morning of Monday, January , staff at the East Loan campus of Preston Tower Primary School discovered that a beer bottle had been thrown through the window of the nursery classroom.The children, aged two to four, had to be kept in one half of the room while the glass was cleaned up and the area was made safe. This took about  minutes.Two days later, a wine bottle was thrown through the window of the neighbouring community room.The children were not affected by this damage but staff resources were erted and maintenance support required.The damage was to the Early Learning and Childcare  nursery building in the grounds of the campus.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWindows at the Preston Tower Primary nursery building were smashed on two separate occasions by bottles having been thrown through the windows a classroom and the neighbouring community room were affected.ldquoThe areas were immediately closed to children and cleared by staff, and the windows were repaired as a priority.ldquoThis senseless behaviour wastes valuable financial resources and means staff have to spend time making the area safe for children to learn and play.ldquoWersquore all disappointed that such a lack of respect would be shown for a nursery building, particularly at a time when children are attending. The children struggle to understand why this would happen.ldquoWe are working with the police and our anti-social behaviour team. We would encourage anyone with information on these incidents to contact police on .

title: b-m-open-new-store-prestonpans

title: gritter-fell-ditch-twice-one-night-clearing-east-lothian-roads
story: As the Courier reported yesterday, the gritter, owned by East Lothian Council, took a tumble just outside Gford on Monday afternoon at about .pm, at Myreside near the Chippendale International School of Furniture.The driver was uninjured, while the vehicle was recovered and ed to its route.It has now emerged that later that night, the same gritter, with a dferent driver, fell off the Bat the crossroads near Danskine, just outside Gford.The driver was again unharmed he was picked up and ed home, while the gritter was recovered at about am on Tuesday, and continued on its route with additional tractor and snow clearing support.After this second incident, two roads linking East Lothian to the Borders were closed.The B road from Townhead near Yester Castle to Cranshaws, and the C to Longformacus, are shut.East Lothian Council urged residents to take note of the local weather forecast, take care and drive to the conditions.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe Band Cwere both closed from Townhead to Cranshaws and Longformacus respectively due to drting snow caused by strong winds.ldquoThese two incidents highlight the hazards our staff experience to keep the roads safe for the people of East Lothian.East Lothian Council has  gritters and  mini tractors available to treat roads and pavements during periods of ice and snow.Since last Friday, up to  people have been involved in the councilrsquos winter maintenance operations, with more than  tonnes of rock salt used on the roads.In adverse weather conditions, a sht pattern is put in place to ensure resources are used as effectively as possible.Responsible for more than , kilometres of road, the council operates a system with, where possible, priority given to treating major roads and important bus routes before ice and snow form.Once these main routes have been treated, minor routes, such as those in housing estates, are treated during normal working hours.The council regularly check and receive weather information specic to East Lothian from the Met Office and aim to carry out treatment before ice forms and snow settles.A council spokesperson added: ldquoDue to the nature of the work, the treatment vehicles can themselves be caught by poor weather conditions, with one instance this week of a gritter coming off the road near Gford.ldquoThankfully, no one was injured and the lorry was back out treating our roads and clearing snow within a few hours.ldquoDrting snow, particularly in rural areas, can block roads and the council will use ploughs, supported by farmers and contractors, title: msp-riverside-medical-practice-cannot-expand-boundary-issues-fixed
story: Colin Beattie MSP said this decision followed talks with Jeane Freeman MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport.Last year, the Primary Care Contractor Organisation outlined plans to alter the practice boundary to take patients from the Blindwells new town development.Construction is set to get under way on the first of the , phase one homes at the former opencast mine site between Prestonpans and Longniddry.Over the next decade and beyond, up to , new homes and community facilities are expected to be built there.Also proposed is a ldquoLevenhall Queen Margaret University extension as part of the boundary change at the Riverside GP practice.The practice is based at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre , along with Inveresk Medical Practice, which is separate.After it merged with Eskbridge Medical Practice, Riverside became the largest practice in East Lothian and one of the biggest in Scotland, with about , patients.Mr Beattie said: ldquoFrom correspondence with local constituents, it was clear to me that action needed to be taken to remedy the ongoing issues in relation to Riverside Medical Practice.ldquoI have spoken with Jeane Freeman, the Cabinet Secretary for Health and Sport, who is now working closely with NHS Lothian to ensure that a solution is found.ldquoIt was decided that the best route forward was to allow no further boundary expansions of the practice until the service is ing at a satisfactory standard.ldquoI am sure that this decision will be welcomed by all those who have concerns about the practice.He added: ldquoOf course, the NHS does not have complete control over the operations of the practice, given that the doctors are simply contracted by the NHS to run this service. However, NHS Lothian will work closely with the management going forward to ensure their budget is managed more effectively, and that the issues at hand are adequately addressed.Members of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council have also told health bosses that the proposed boundary expansion would be ldquoa step in the wrong direction.The group contacted the Primary Care Contractor Organisation, stressing that it was ldquoabsolutely opposed to any change in the boundary area.Members also called for a meeting with health bosses, which took place recently at the practice and involved: Irene Tait, community council chairperson Margaret Stewart, community council secretary Holly Kilday, a community council member Dr Richard Fairclough and Dr Joana Stenke of Riverside Medical Practice ward councillors Stuart Currie and Katie Mackie Iain Gorman, East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos head of operations and Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell, chairperson of East Lothian Integration Joint Board.The community councillors highlighted complaints they had received from members of the community, including:A statement issued by the community council following the discussion said: ldquoWe wondered why on earth the practice would want to take on more of a workload when clearly they are not coping with what they have to deal with at present.ldquoThe practice acknowledged the fact that they had undergone many changes in the last few years, not least the fact that they are on their third telephone system.ldquoThe practice also stated they will need to step up to the mark with a communication plan, making sure that everyone in our community is aware of how the practice is working and what options are available to them.ldquoThe expectation from the public is,they phone for a doctorsrsquo appointment, they will see a doctor and this is not always going to be the case.ldquoWhen you call you will be given two options, same day or non-urgent, and this will enable the staff to put you on to the right person who can help and this could be NHS , paramedics, physio, mental health or occupational therapistor alternatively, a doctornecessary on the same day.Wrong direction ldquoWe discussed the boundaries and made them aware that we felt that to take on Blindwells would be a step in the wrong direction.ldquoThe meeting was quite positive and hopefully, moving forward, we will keep in touch with the practice and they with us so that everyone is kept informed.Dr Stenke and Dr Fairclough issued a joint statement, saying: ldquoWe were delighted to meet with the Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council representatives and local councillors. We felt it was a really positive opportunity to discuss many of the changes that have happened in Musselburgh over the last few years to stabilise and develop primary care services.ldquoIt is really important for us at Riverside to understand the views of the community we serve, which can be hugely supportive in improving services. For example, feedback on our old phone system helped us to understand the issues that our patients were experiencing and led to us developing a new telephone system that was more suitable for our patientsrsquo needs as well as those of the practice.ldquoRiverside, along with other practices in the county, are collaborating with and supporting East Lothianrsquos Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos plan to grow health services to meet the needs of a growing population.ldquoWe remain keen to improve our engagement and communication with the local community, and the meeting was a positive step to build links with local groups.ldquoWe are grateful to the community council representatives and local councillors for taking the time to visit us at Riverside Medical Practice and we look forward to developing a closer and collaborative relationship with them.An East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership spokesperson said: ldquoWe thought the meeting with Riverside and the community council was very positive. We were impressed by Riversidersquos commitment to engaging with the community and communicating developments. We look forward to supporting them in any way that we can.Councillor Mackie added: ldquoIt was a helpful meeting with community stakeholders and local GPs. There was recognition that previous changes to the Riverside practice could have been better communicated to patients and a real willingness to improve engagement with the local community.ldquoHopefully this is the start of really meaningful engagement with local GPs at Riverside.

title: claim-buildings-haddington-street-left-shaking-large-vehicles
story: Concerns about the speed of vehicles and the condition of the buildings on the historic street were raised at Haddingtonrsquos community council meeting.Members heard from David Barrett, who lives near the busy town centre street and felt that something needed to be done.However, he claimed he had raised the issue with East Lothian Council previously ndash only to allegedly be told that nothing could be done until the buildings started falling onto the street.Mr Barrett said: ldquoI think one of the paradoxes about Market Street is we all see it during the day and Friday afternoon, it is more like Oxford Circus. You can walk faster than the traffic.ldquoBut between am and am, and between pm and am, huge agricultural vehicles and HGVs actually hit  miles plus per hour through the town and our buildings shake, they physically shake.Mr Barrett was keen to see something done to slow vehicles down on the busy street.He said: ldquoIrsquom suggesting that some type of traffic calming is very necessary to preserve the fabric of the historic buildings.However, the idea of large vehicles doing more than  miles per hour on Market Street was refuted by Rab Moran.The community councillor, who was an HGV driver for about  years, said: ldquoI used to be an HGV driver and there is no way an articulated lorry or anything  for that matter clatters along Market Street at  miles per hour.ldquoYou sometimes donrsquot get up to  miles per hour going along there.Mr Moran stressed that it was a rural community and there were occasions where farm machinery needed to use the roads.Fellow community councillor Chris McEwan said there were issues with putting in traffic calming measures, such as speed humps.He said: ldquoSpeed humps are going to be absolutely useless to anything over a normal car size.ldquoThey are designed so ambulances can carry over.ldquoThey would not slow down trucks or anything .A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed that the issue was being investigated.She said: ldquoWe are aware of Mr Barrettrsquos concerns and have advised that the council is currently looking at measures concerning traffic movement in and around Haddington.ldquoThese plans may include consideration of traffic calming options to reduce speeds in certain areas.

title: met-office-name-storms-names-ruled
story: After a mild start to the year, we have been battered by heavy rain and severe gales.But who comes up with the names for storms and whats next Why do the Met Office name storms The Met Office first decided to givestorms a namein  with the first one named Abigail in November .The hope was that naming severe storms wouldmake people more aware of them and how dangerous they can be.And it makes iteasier to follow the progress of a storm on the TV, radio, or on social media,it has a name.Can I suggest a storm name Every summer the Met Office andMet Eacuteireann askpeople to send in their ideas for future storm names.Look out for their #NameOurStorms campaign on social media around July this year for the chance for your name to be included.A new list of names will be compiled jointly between Met Eacuteireann,the Met Office and KNMIin September for the following   storm season.What are the storm names for this year Weve already had:Dennis is set to arrive this weekend and then weve got:Names alternate between male and female and run from A-Z based on some of the more popular names suggested to the Met Office as well as reflecting the ersity of Britain, Ireland and the Netherlands.To ensure the Met Office is in line with the US National Hurricane Centre naming conventions, names which begin with the letters Q, U, X, Y and Z are not included.Are there any names the Met Office has ruled out Among the names suggested to the Met Office, officials have rejected anything that isnt a proper name.That includes:Apocalypse, Baldrick, Big Boss, Gnasher, Hot Brew, root ripper, Stormageddon, Ssswetcaroline, Vader, Voldermort and branch wobbler.Other rejected names included Hammer, Hades,Forkbeard, Megatron andIn A Teacup.

title: coronavirus-advice-issued-queen-margaret-university

title: tims-tales-gift-magic-space
story: A STORYTELLER friend recently gted us an articial electric log stove and hearth surround with mantle piece.She is an expert at recycling, and placed it where the real fireplace used to be and it looks fantastic. When the fire effect is switched on, it gives an impressive imitation of a real one.Our small terraced house once had a real fire place, of course, but like so many it was modernised before I moved in, and it was filled in and central heating installed.Yet I am old enough to have lived all my childhood in the lsquos and lsquos without experiencing central heating! It did exist, of course, just not in the houses I lived in as a child!One memory I have is of arriving home from school on a cold winterrsquos afternoon and seeing the smoke coming from the chimney of the church house we lived in at the east end of the Pans. My father had lit the fire early and I still remember its welcoming warmth, and the way it crackled and danced as it defrosted my face and hands. Me and my brothers sat by it, jostling for the best space.Donrsquot get me wrong, Irsquom not complaining about central heating! I know Irsquom lucky to have a warm house and never take it for granted. We donrsquot use the lsquofirersquo for heat, that would be too expensive. But we switch it on for atmosphere. And the effect on the younger kids has been immediate. They sit by it, lie on blankets by it reading and playing and telling stories. I forget that they have little personal experience of having a hearth, even an articial one. The novelty will wane, perhaps, but I hope the cosy pleasure of it wonrsquot.Itrsquos not just the kids, as my we and I love sitting by it in the evening. Wersquove even moved some of the furniture, so this pretend but convincing fireplace, rather than the telly, has become the main focal point of the living room.You could say Irsquom easily pleased, and I suppose thatrsquos true. But our friends have commented on it too, one saying ldquoit really has given your house a dferent atmosphere as he sat by it with the wind howling outside.The hearth has traditionally been the soul of a house. The family would sit by it, soak in the warmth and watch the flames, while telling stories and talking. It was a draw for social communion. Visitors would be welcomed with a place by it and most of the cooking would have taken place there too. The old saying ldquolang may yer lums reekindicated the importance of a lit hearth as a symbol of wellbeing and good fortune.No wonder so many traditions and ceremonies were centred around the hearth. People used to leave objects buried within or near it. There were ious reasons for this: to capture bad spirits that may come down the chimney, for good luck or to deflect a witchrsquos spell. The hearth was seen as a kind of spiritual portal, to be defended and made safe, not just physically.The hearth was also a focus of many ceremonies that marked the changing seasons. The Celtic calendar is full of such events, Imbolc being the most recent. And of course there were the daily rituals of banking up the fire at night, and reviving it in the morning, and keeping it going. All these simple tasks are now fast fading into folk memory.Today, screens are more likely to be the focal point of our homes. Itrsquos kind of unavoidable, of course, and I claim no moral high ground of this issue. But the truth is they drug our senses and dull our conviviality, and, like many parents, we have tried to limit their use in our house. It has felt like a losing battle with my children who, I understand, live in a very dferent childhood to mine. And I readily concede itrsquos got lots of benefits, even though at times I may sound like an old dinosaur lamenting the passing of the Jurassic age.But the arrival of our fake woodburning stove has transformed our house in a way that shows we have lost something in the lsquomodernisingrsquo of our homes. As a storyteller, I have come to understand the importance of a hearth as a focal point for gathering it has the power to bring people together, to share warmth and light but also each otherrsquos presence and social connection. As the freezing wind rages outside, it is a magical space.That magic has been the true gt from my storyteller friend, and she wisely knew it. While much is missing from an articial fire, including the smell and sound of the real thing, our ancestral instinct still kicks in by the visual sight of a flickering hearth.So now my instructions to switch off the screens is more readily obeyed, because it signals time to get together around the fire and lsquobe together properlyrsquo to tell stories and challenge each other with riddles.Burnrsquos poem The Cotterrsquos Saturday Night now has new meaning in our house:To meet their dad, wi flichterin noise and glee.His wee bit ingle, blinkin bonilie,His clean hearth-stane, his thrty wiersquos smile,The lisping infant, prattling on his knee,Does arsquo his weary kiaugh and care beguile,An makes him quite forget his labor and his toil.

title: waterside-bistro-chief-takes-castle-inn-dirleton
story: Brothers Jack and James Findlay have been at the helm of the Waterside Bistro, next to the River Tyne in Haddington, for more than two-and-a-half years.The eaterie was founded by their dad Jim, who also previously ran The Drovers Inn in East Linton, and The Rocks on Dunbarrsquos Marine Road.Now, Jack is expanding the empire by taking over The Castle Inn.He told the Courier: ldquoWe have had quite a soft opening, we just opened yesterday [last Wednesday].ldquoI think the area is lovely and my dad was born in Dirleton, so there is a little bit of heritage there.ldquoWe will be basing it a lot on the Waterside model and obviously myself and my brother will be working alongside each other but from afar.ldquoWe have had tremendous success at the Waterside and we both felt it was probably the right time to look where.ldquoThe Castle Inn was the perfect fit for us.ldquoIt will be myself here and my brother is still based in Haddington.ldquoMy dad is lsquoretiredrsquo but will just be popping in and making sure we are going in the right direction.Twenty-eight-year-old Jack said they already had a good team in place and there were no plans for any ldquodrastic changes.A focus would be placed on locally sourced food, with a daily list of specials.He added: ldquoI would also like to mention the former owners John Dawson and Bert DrsquoAgostino, and want to pay a bit of a tribute to them for their fine work in the trade.ldquoJohn has been fantastic with me and very helpful.

title: bench-put-place-memory-tranent-legend-bobby-marr
story: Bobby Marr, who ran a greengrocer and florist on Tranentrsquos Winton Place for nearly  years, passed away last July.The -year-old was a familiar face to many in Tranent town centre, with hundreds attending his funeral.Marion Hoggan was heavily involved in the fundraising for the bench for Mr Marr, who had colon cancer.She said: ldquoI did not manage the funeral due to work commitments and I felt that I wanted to do something for him. I came up with the idea of the bench and spoke to the family and they were quite keen on it.ldquoMyself and a couple of friends did a fundraising day at the Store Club on January .ldquoIt was a sell-out ndash it sold out within a week of talking about it ndash and a lot of people did not get tickets.ldquoDavid Martin was the host and we had Derryn McKillop, Jim McCran, Donna Howe, Jack Robertson, Dean Jones and Mags Foster there.ldquoThey all entertained us all day, free of charge, and gave up their precious time.In total, the event raised more than pound,, with any money above the cost of the bench being donated to the oncology department at the Western General Hospital in Edinburgh.Mrs Hoggan described Mr Marr, who lived on the townrsquos Kennedy Crescent, as ldquovery kind and ldquoa true gentleman and said he always took an interest in the bowling exploits of her daughters Kim and Dee.She thanked local businesses and shopkeepers for the donation of raffle prizes and cash donations for the fundraiser last month.She also paid tribute to David Forrest and Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council for working alongside East Lothian Council to see the bench put in place.Mr Forrest, chairman of the townrsquos community council, was also among those at the unveiling ceremony off the townrsquos High Street.He said: ldquoI remember Bobby Marr in his shop and I remember when his parents owned it. I was at school with Bobbyrsquos older brother and Bobby was always a nice bloke, always friendly and always helpful.ldquoThe shop has been part of Tranent for as long as I have been in Tranent.More than  people turned out off Tranent High Street at the war memorial on Tuesday afternoon for the unveiling of the bench.Councillor Kenny McLeod, who lives in the town, was among those at the short ceremony, which took place on what would have been Mr Marrrsquos th birthday.Mr McLeod was delighted with the event and felt it was a fitting gesture.He said: ldquoThere was a big turnout of about  folk.

story: Planning permission for a residential development and cemetery for land at Newtonlees, to the east of the town, was given in .Detailed plans for the housing scheme on the site were submitted to title: major-changes-north-berwick-high-street-trialled-12-months
story: They centre on widening the narrow pavements, primarily achieved through the loss of parking spaces.The plans were agreed by the Charrette Implementation Group, a sub-group of North Berwick Coastal Area Partnership.The changes aim to enhance pedestrian safety, accessibility and improve parking from Market Place up to and including Quality Street and Kirk Ports.Increasing the turnover of parking spaces in the town centre and the amount of short-stay parking are also key goals.A low-level kerb would be introduced on the widened pavements and -minute short stay parking enforced.Long-stay spaces in Law Road car park would become short-stay -minute lsquono rsquo berths while additional parking would be created on Quality Street.These plans for North Berwick High Street show existing parkingand proposed parkingunder the plans.
